Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Enabling Techologies for Energy-Centric Mobile App Design to Extend Mobile Device Battery Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project can be summarized as follows. (1) Societal impact: The PI's initial ground-breaking research on dissecting the energy drain of AngryBirds and exposing its inefficiency was covered by over 500 news media outlets worldwide. This interest reflects the growing importance of mobile computing devices in all strata of society. The importance of this work is heightened by smartphones being an important enabler of Internet access for disadvantaged people in both developed and developing countries, and hence being an important tool in overcoming the "digital divide". (2) Commercial impact: The technologies developed in this project for enabling energy-efficient app design will lead to longer battery life, which in turn leads to longer mobile eye time of users, which ultimately translates into millions of dollars of increased revenue to large businesses today as they transition towards mobile. The commercial outcome of the proposed SBIR project will lead to a marketable product and/or process. (3) Technological impact: This work will extend the performance profiling technology foundational to the software industry to the energy dimension, which is critical to the mobile software industry.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will tackle several key technical challenges in helping app developers to write energy-efficient apps, which holds the promise of extending the battery life of mobile devices and ultimately improving user mobile experience. The research objectives are (1) to develop energy analytics of mobile apps running on millions of users' phones and incentivize developers to adopt an energy-centric app design paradigm; (2) to develop technologies for app energy profiling with multiple resolutions which will make it easier for developers to adopt them in their app design process; (3) to develop energy-efficiency programming guidelines and templates for helping app developers to write energy-efficient apps in the first place. These objectives pose significant technical challenges. While similar challenges on the performance metric (e.g. running time) have been well studied for traditional software, in particular in high-performance computing, this project will take them to the energy dimension for the mobile software industry, which has not been attempted before. The company expects to develop the first set of solutions to these fundamental challenges in optimizing the energy drain of millions of mobile apps.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase I project aims to develop key enabling technologies and software tools for helping the developers of the 2 million and growing number of mobile apps to optimize their apps' energy drain. Towards this goal, the project has accomplished the following outcomes:

 

(1) Intellectual merit.

We developed the beta release of Eagle Tester, an energy testing framework designed to be used with Continuous integrations platforms such as Jenkins (https://jenkins.io/). Upon each code commit to an app, the CI platform can trigger automated battery drain tests using Eagle Tester. If the tests show that the energy consumption is suddenly higher than with previous code versions, the build will fail and the code commit will be rejected. Thus Eagle Tester provides app developers with a much-needed capability - an automated battery testing platform that can catch the existence of all energy glitches hidden among potentially millions of lines of complex app source code before the app is released to run on millions of handsets. We developed solutions to overcome key challenges in developing such an automated testing tool, including high testing accuracy, quick turnaround time, and seamless CI integration.

 

We developed a major extension to Eagle Tester, a debugging tool that enables  app developers to precisely pinpoint energy glitches at the source-code level, by breaking down the energy drain of the entire phone into phone components (e.g. CPU, network) and then into running apps and further into methods and threads in the apps' source code. The previous version of Eagle Debugger cannot explain the root cause of the energy hotspot or automatically prescribes fixes. We developed Eagle Debugger DiffView to give source-code-level insights into why one app execution consums more energy than the other. Eagle Debugger DiffView takes two similar apps, or two versions of the same app, and identifies the more energy-efficient implementation of the same app function or task by directly comparing the energy drain of the two apks at the source-code level. We developed solutions to overcome key challenges faced in developing DiffView, including user interaction variations in different runs of the apps compared, finding identical executions of two apps being compared, and finding parts of distinct call graphs of two apps (e.g. Spotify and Pandora) that perform the same functions (e.g. music playback).

 

(2) Broader impact.

Commercially, the project developed enabling technologies that will have a significant, long lasting impact on the app industry (estimated $101B in 2020). Energy-efficient apps lead to longer battery life, which in turn leads to longer mobile time of users, which ultimately translates into millions of dollars of increased revenue as all major businesses today are shifting towards mobile. The commercial outcome of the proposed SBIR project has led to a marketable product. The technologies developed will also have a societal impact. It will help to bridge the digital divide by enabling developing energy efficient apps that previously could not but now can run on low-end handsets which dominant developing countries.
